content: f87dad3b-b00a-4582-b200-3452a8deafb5 eng Ann Fritz North Dakota Department of Health - Division of Water Quality 701.328.5162 918 E. Divide Bismarck ND 58501-1947 USA 2014-11-03T11:44:35 ISO 19115:2003/19139 1.0 1904 Watershed Boundary Dataset 2014-10-17 1 North Dakota North Dakota Department of Health-Division of Water Quality This data set is a complete digital hydrologic unit boundary layer to the Watershed (10-digit) 5th level for the entire state of North Dakota. This data set consists of geo-referenced digital data and associated attributes created in accordance with the "Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary Dataset; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3 - Third Edition" (2012). http://pubs.usgs.gov/tm/tm11a3/. Polygons are attributed with hydrologic unit codes for 5th level subwatersheds, name, size, Updates made to correct HU_10 and HU_12 names to be consistent with National Standards; incorporate changes made to include Canadian hydrologic units and correct mistakes in original dataset. PROVISIONAL DATA! This data is presented 'as is.' This data set contains only those polygons that are within the subbasins that touch the borders of North Dakota. For WBD boundaries outside of this footprint, please go to http://nhd.usgs.gov/wbd.html and click "Get Data". October 17, 2014: Update includes corrected 10-digit hydrologic unit codes for the Missouri River (Region 10). Updated linework in selected areas in the Missouri River basin. These data are considered the most recent updates to the data by the ND WBD Data Steward. They may differ than what is obtained from the USGS National Map website, Watershed Boundary Dataset. March 20, 2014: Inclusion of HUC10 polygons for the entire Souris Subregion and updates for bordering regions of MT, WY, SD, and MN. The Souris River data has not been approved yet by the Federal Technical Review Team. To download the complete WBD for the U.S. go to http://nhd.usgs.gov/wbd.html and click on "get data" March 26, 2013: Changes made in Devils Lake and James River Headwaters subbasin to correct coding, align more closely with 1:24K NHD and bring attributes in compliance with current WBD Standards. Ottertail River subbasin, which is located entirely within the state of MN, is no longer included with this dataset. January 31st, 2013: HUC10 changes were made to 0901000203 to add add "Upper Des Lacs Lake" to the HU_10_NAME field for that portion north of the Canadian border. Also, changes were made to HUC10 1006000700. The HU_10_NAME was changed from "Brush Creek" to "Brush Lake" due to the fact that there is no "Brush Creek" in the watershed. Additionally, the HU_12_NAME was changed on 100600070001 to "Marsland Slough" and on 100600070002 to "Brush Lake". December 29, 2011: ND10 changes include many updates and corrections in the Souris River subregion (0901) plus changes made in neighboring states. Please see http://www.nd.gov/gis/help/faq/ (#11) for information regarding HU12_NAME field. December 12, 2010: Changes made to incorporate subbasin boundaries that extend across the Canadian border, incorporate changes made to neighboring state's datasets, as well as to correct coding and naming mistakes that were present in the original dataset. The Watershed and Subwatershed hydrologic unit boundaries provide a uniquely identified and uniform method of subdividing large drainage areas. The smaller sized 6th level sub-watersheds (up to 250,000 acres) are useful for numerous application programs supported by a variety of local, State, and Federal Agencies. This data set is intended to be used as a tool for water-resource management and planning activities, particularly for site-specific and localized studies requiring a level of detail provided by large-scale map information. The dataset is seamless and, for the most part, a nationally consistant geospatial database. March 26, 2013: Changes made in Devils Lake and James River Headwaters subbasin to correct coding, align more closely with 1:24K NHD and bring attributes in compliance with current WBD Standards. Ottertail River subbasin, which is located entirely within the state of MN, is no longer included with this dataset. These changes have not yet been approved by the Federal Technical Review team. To download the complete WBD for the U.S. go to http://nhd.usgs.gov/wbd.html and click on "get data". January 31st, 2013: HUC10 changes were made to 0901000203 to add add "Upper Des Lacs Lake" to the HU_10_NAME field for that portion north of the Canadian border. Also, changes were made to HUC10 1006000700. The HU_10_NAME was changed from "Brush Creek" to "Brush Lake" due to the fact that there is no "Brush Creek" in the watershed. Additionally, the HU_12_NAME was changed on 100600070001 to "Marsland Slough" and on 100600070002 to "Brush Lake". December 29, 2011: ND10 changes include many updates and corrections in the Souris River subregion (0901) plus changes made in neighboring states. Please see http://www.nd.gov/gis/help/faq/ (#11) for information regarding HU12_NAME field. December 12, 2010: Changes made to incorporate subbasin boundaries that extend across the Canadian border, incorporate changes made to neighboring state's datasets, as well as to correct coding and naming mistakes that were present in the original dataset. The Watershed and Subwatershed hydrologic unit boundaries provide a uniquely identified and uniform method of subdividing large drainage areas. The smaller sized 6th level sub-watersheds (up to 250,000 acres) are useful for numerous application programs supported by a variety of local, State, and Federal Agencies. This data set is intended to be used as a tool for water-resource management and planning activities, particularly for site-specific and localized studies requiring a level of detail provided by large-scale map information. The dataset is seamless and, for the most part, a nationally consistant geospatial database. Funding and support for the Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD) were provided by the Natural Resources Conservation Service, the Environmental Protection Agency, and the United States Geological Survey. Representatives from the U.S. Geological Survey and Environmental Protection Agency contributed a substantial amount of time and salary towards quality review and updating of the dataset in order to meet the Federal Standards for Delineation of Hydrologic Unit Boundaries. Ann Fritz North Dakota Department of Health - Division of Water Quality 701-328-5162 918 E. Divide Ave. Bismarck ND 58501-1947 afritz@nd.gov Please email questions and requests. watershedboundarydataset_s.png thumbnail png watershedboundarydataset.png large_thumbnail png Sub-basin boundaries WBD HUC Subwatershed Hydrologic Unit Code Basin Sub-region Watershed Boundary Dataset Hydrologic Units Watershed Boundaries Watershed Region Red River of the North North Dakota Missouri River James River Souris River The distributor shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of this data, based on the description of appropriate/inappropriate uses described in this metadata document. It is strongly recommended that this data is directly acquired from the distributor and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. These data should not be used at scales greater than 1:24,000 for the purpose of identifying hydrographic watershed boundary feature locations in the U.S.A. The U.S. Department of Agriculture makes no claims for the data's suitability for other purposes. U.S. Department of Agriculture should be acknowledged as the data source in products derived from these data. The Watershed Boundary Dataset is public information and may be interpreted by all organizations, agencies, units of government, or others based on needs; however, they are responsible for the appropriate application of the data. Federal, State, or local regulatory bodies are not to reassign to the U.S. Department of Agriculture or the Natural Resources Conservation Service any authority for the decisions they make. The Natural Resources Conservation Service will not perform any evaluations of these maps or purposes related solely to State or local regulatory programs. Photographic or digital enlargement of these maps to scales greater than that at which they were originally delineated can result in misrepresentation of the data. If enlarged, the maps will not include the fine detail that would be appropriate for mapping at the small scale. Digital data files are periodically updated. Files are dated, and users are responsible for obtaining the latest version of the data from the source distributor. eng boundaries -104.5 -96.5 45.5 49.5 User-defined n/a Ann Fritz North Dakota Department of Health - Division of Water Quality 701.328.5162 918 W. Divide Ave. Bismarck ND 58501-1947 USA afritz@nd.gov please e-mail with data requests. http://www.nd.gov/gis WWW:LINK-1.0-http--link NDGIS web site NDGIS web site http://www.nd.gov/gis/apps/DataDownload/?clipping=Full&coord=ND83-SF&format=SHAPE&layers=NDHUB.HUC2_REGION WWW:LINK-1.0-http--related Download Hydrologic Unit 2 Regions Download Hydrologic Unit 2 Regions http://www.nd.gov/gis/apps/DataDownload/?clipping=Full&coord=ND83-SF&format=SHAPE&layers=NDHUB.HUC4_SUBREGION WWW:LINK-1.0-http--related Download Hydrologic Unit 4 SubRegions Download Hydrologic Unit 4 SubRegions http://www.nd.gov/gis/apps/DataDownload/?clipping=Full&coord=ND83-SF&format=SHAPE&layers=NDHUB.HUC6_BASIN WWW:LINK-1.0-http--related Download Hydrologic Unit 6 Basins Download Hydrologic Unit 6 Basins http://www.nd.gov/gis/apps/DataDownload/?clipping=Full&coord=ND83-SF&format=SHAPE&layers=NDHUB.HUC8_SUBBASIN WWW:LINK-1.0-http--related Download Hydrologic Unit 8 SubBasins Download Hydrologic Unit 8 SubBasins http://www.nd.gov/gis/apps/DataDownload/?clipping=Full&coord=ND83-SF&format=SHAPE&layers=NDHUB.HUC10_WATERSHED WWW:LINK-1.0-http--related Download Hydrologic Unit 10 Watersheds Download Hydrologic Unit 10 Watersheds http://www.nd.gov/gis/apps/DataDownload/?clipping=Full&coord=ND83-SF&format=SHAPE&layers=NDHUB.HUC12_SUBWATERSHED WWW:LINK-1.0-http--related Download Hydrologic Unit 12 SubWatersheds Download Hydrologic Unit 12 SubWatersheds http://www.nd.gov/gis/apps/DataDownload/?clipping=Full&coord=ND83-SF&format=SHAPE&layers=NDHUB.HUC12_LINE WWW:LINK-1.0-http--related Download Hydrologic Unit 12 Boundary Line Download Hydrologic Unit 12 Boundary Line http://ndgishub.nd.gov/arcgis/services/All_Hydrography/MapServer/WMSServer? OGC:WMS-1.3.0-http-get-map Hydrologic Unit 2 Region Hydrologic Unit 2 Region http://ndgishub.nd.gov/arcgis/services/All_Hydrography/MapServer/WMSServer? OGC:WMS-1.3.0-http-get-map Hydrologic Unit 4 Subregion Hydrologic Unit 4 Subregion http://ndgishub.nd.gov/arcgis/services/All_Hydrography/MapServer/WMSServer? OGC:WMS-1.3.0-http-get-map Hydrologic Unit 6 Basin Hydrologic Unit 6 Basin http://ndgishub.nd.gov/arcgis/services/All_Hydrography/MapServer/WMSServer? OGC:WMS-1.3.0-http-get-map Hydrologic Unit 8 Subbasin Hydrologic Unit 8 Subbasin http://ndgishub.nd.gov/arcgis/services/All_Hydrography/MapServer/WMSServer? OGC:WMS-1.3.0-http-get-map Hydrologic Unit 10 Watershed Hydrologic Unit 10 Watershed http://ndgishub.nd.gov/arcgis/services/All_Hydrography/MapServer/WMSServer? OGC:WMS-1.3.0-http-get-map Hydrologic Unit 12 Subwatershed Hydrologic Unit 12 Subwatershed http://ndgishub.nd.gov/arcgis/services/All_Hydrography/MapServer/WMSServer? OGC:WMS-1.3.0-http-get-map Hydrologic Unit 12 Boundary Line Hydrologic Unit 12 Boundary Line http://ndgishub.nd.gov/ArcGIS/rest/services/All_Hydrography/MapServer WWW:LINK-1.0-http--related Esri REST including WMS Esri REST including WMS http://ndgishub.nd.gov/ArcGIS/rest/services/Features/Hydrography/MapServer WWW:LINK-1.0-http--related Esri REST including WFS and KML Esri REST including WFS and KML Level 5 (10-digit) watersheds were delineated within a nested hierarchical structure using the existing Level 4 (8-digit) watershed delineation as a starting framework. When neccessary, corrections were made to the fourth level line. Level 6 (12-digit) subwatersheds were then nested within the 5th level framework. The typical size of a level 6 watershed is 10,000 to 40,000 acres. The order of precedence for establishing the pour point of a sub-watershed is: (1) at the outlet of a lake or pond; (2) at a confluence; (3) at some topographic feature, such as a natural gap in topography; (4) at a dam; (5) to meet the acreage limitations of the Federal Standard. Those subbasins that were not transferred to mylar base the following steps were completed: 1) Prior to 2005, each of the paper quad sheets were scanned at a resolution of 600 dpi in black and white. After 2005, the paper quad sheets were scanned at resolution of 300dpi in full color. 2) The resultant image was rotated to a proper cardinal direction orientation and saved 3) The scanned image was imported into ArcMap and georeferenced 4) An empty shapefile was created and defined in ArcCatalog 5) Linework was head's up digitized into this empty shapefile at a scale of approximately 1:11000 ( for those subbasins completed prior to June, 2004); after June, 2004, heads-up digitizing was completed at a scale of approximatley 1:5000. 6) Shapefile was converted to ArcInfo coverage format 7) Line topology and polygon topology were built (to get attribute tables for both) 8) Labels were created 9) Required HUC items were added to the line and polygon attribute tables 10) The coverage projection definition was set to UTM, NAD83 11) HUC code attributes were added to polygons 12) HUC code attributes were added to lines Many agencies contributed to the creation of the dataset using this process; specifically the ND State Water Commission, the U.S. Forest Service, the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, the ND Game and Fish Department and the ND Department of Health. They all had a hand in creating this dataset, and contributed to it's review and improvement. For subbasins , 09020313, 10130202, 10130204, 10130205, 10130206,(USGS vectorized) 09020105, 10160001, 10160002, 10160003 (SWC) the original hard copy watershed delineations were transferred to a mylar overlay quad map 1) Each of the mylar sheets were scanned in full color at a resolution of 300dpi 2) The resultant images were rotated to proper cardinal direction orientation and the color depth was reduced to two colors(black and white) and saved 3) Vectorization AML was run to convert the images linework ArcInfo coverage format a) Image was converted to an ArcInfo Grid format b) Grid was vectorized c) Linework was splined d) Coverage was georeferenced and transformed 4) Once all coverages were transformed, all were appended into one large coverage 5) Artifacts from scanned image were deleted including tics, line color script, and basin id script 6) Edgematching clean-up performed 7) Line topology and polygon topology were built (to get attribute tables for both) 8) Labels were created 9) Required HUC items were added to the line and polygon attribute tables 10) The coverage projection definition was set to UTM, zone 14 NAD83 11) HUC code attributes were added to polygons 12) HUC code attributes were added to lines This work was generously completed by the ND State Water Commission and the U.S. Geological Survey Water Resource Office in Bismarck for the subbasins as indicated. 2002-01-01T00:00:00 For the Upper Heart, Pembina, Cedar Creek, Lower Cannonball and Upper Cannonball rivers (09020313, 10130202, 10130204, 10130205, 10130206), NRCS personnel delineated hydrologic unit boundaries then inked mylar overlays that were scanned and converted to .rlc format. Scanned lines were then vectorized in ArcInfo. The ND SWC and their contractor, HUD, Inc. completed a similar process for the Devils Lake basin, James River Headwaters, Pipestem, Upper James and Elm-maple rivers. See process step for more description. 24000 Mylar tracings of hydrologic unit boundaries Natural Resource Conservation Service - ND State Office Aerial images from the cities of Bismarck, Mandan and Lincoln as well as aerial images from Cass County, ND were used for further refinement of line placement. 6000 The North Dakota Geological Survey contributed all the 7.5 minute quad maps for this project. They were the base map for all delineations. 24000 Provided basemap for heads-up digitizing, verification of line placement. 24000 Digital Raster Graphic U.S.Geological Survey Provided additional detail when USGS Topographic maps were outdated, or known modifications to the landscape have occurred. Use of NAIP imagery to refine hydrologic unit boundaries is indicated by OTH in the LINESOURCE field. 12000 National Agricultural Imagery Program USDA-FSA-APFO

        <gmd:abstract>
          <gco:CharacterString>This data set is a complete digital hydrologic unit boundary layer to the Watershed (10-digit) 5th level for the entire state of North Dakota. This data set consists of geo-referenced digital data and associated attributes created in accordance with the "Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary Dataset; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3 - Third Edition" (2012). http://pubs.usgs.gov/tm/tm11a3/. Polygons are attributed with hydrologic unit codes for 5th level subwatersheds, name, size, Updates made to correct HU_10 and HU_12 names to be consistent with National Standards; incorporate changes made to include Canadian hydrologic units and correct mistakes in original dataset.</gco:CharacterString>
        </gmd:abstract>
        <gmd:purpose>
          <gco:CharacterString>PROVISIONAL DATA!  This data is presented 'as is.'  
This data set contains only those polygons that are within the subbasins that touch the borders of North Dakota. For WBD boundaries outside of this footprint, please go to http://nhd.usgs.gov/wbd.html and click "Get Data". 

October 17, 2014: Update includes corrected 10-digit hydrologic unit codes for the Missouri River (Region 10).  Updated linework in selected areas in the Missouri River basin.  These data are considered the most recent updates to the data by the ND WBD Data Steward.  They may differ than what is obtained from the USGS National Map website, Watershed Boundary Dataset.

March 20, 2014: Inclusion of HUC10 polygons for the entire Souris Subregion and updates for bordering regions of MT, WY, SD, and MN.  The Souris River data has not been approved yet by the Federal Technical Review Team.   To download the complete WBD for the U.S. go to http://nhd.usgs.gov/wbd.html and click on "get data"

March 26, 2013: Changes made in Devils Lake and James River Headwaters subbasin to correct coding, align more closely with 1:24K NHD and bring attributes in compliance with current WBD Standards. Ottertail River subbasin, which is located entirely within the state of MN, is no longer included with this dataset.
 
January 31st, 2013: HUC10 changes were made to 0901000203 to add add "Upper Des Lacs Lake" to the HU_10_NAME field for that portion north of the Canadian border. Also, changes were made to HUC10 1006000700. The HU_10_NAME was changed from "Brush Creek" to "Brush Lake" due to the fact that there is no "Brush Creek" in the watershed. Additionally, the HU_12_NAME was changed on 100600070001 to "Marsland Slough" and on 100600070002 to "Brush Lake". 

December 29, 2011: ND10 changes include many updates and corrections in the Souris River subregion (0901) plus changes made in neighboring states. Please see http://www.nd.gov/gis/help/faq/ (#11) for information regarding HU12_NAME field. 

December 12, 2010: Changes made to incorporate subbasin boundaries that extend across the Canadian border, incorporate changes made to neighboring state's datasets, as well as to correct coding and naming mistakes that were present in the original dataset. 

The Watershed and Subwatershed hydrologic unit boundaries provide a uniquely identified and uniform method of subdividing large drainage areas. The smaller sized 6th level sub-watersheds (up to 250,000 acres) are useful for numerous application programs supported by a variety of local, State, and Federal Agencies. This data set is intended to be used as a tool for water-resource management and planning activities, particularly for site-specific and localized studies requiring a level of detail provided by large-scale map information. The dataset is seamless and, for the most part, a nationally consistant geospatial database.

March 26, 2013: Changes made in Devils Lake and James River Headwaters subbasin to correct coding, align more closely with 1:24K NHD and bring attributes in compliance with current WBD Standards. Ottertail River subbasin, which is located entirely within the state of MN, is no longer included with this dataset. These changes have not yet been approved by the Federal Technical Review team. To download the complete WBD for the U.S. go to http://nhd.usgs.gov/wbd.html and click on "get data". 

January 31st, 2013: HUC10 changes were made to 0901000203 to add add "Upper Des Lacs Lake" to the HU_10_NAME field for that portion north of the Canadian border. Also, changes were made to HUC10 1006000700. The HU_10_NAME was changed from "Brush Creek" to "Brush Lake" due to the fact that there is no "Brush Creek" in the watershed. Additionally, the HU_12_NAME was changed on 100600070001 to "Marsland Slough" and on 100600070002 to "Brush Lake".

December 29, 2011: ND10 changes include many updates and corrections in the Souris River subregion (0901) plus changes made in neighboring states. Please see http://www.nd.gov/gis/help/faq/ (#11) for information regarding HU12_NAME field. 

December 12, 2010: Changes made to incorporate subbasin boundaries that extend across the Canadian border, incorporate changes made to neighboring state's datasets, as well as to correct coding and naming mistakes that were present in the original dataset. The Watershed and Subwatershed hydrologic unit boundaries provide a uniquely identified and uniform method of subdividing large drainage areas. The smaller sized 6th level sub-watersheds (up to 250,000 acres) are useful for numerous application programs supported by a variety of local, State, and Federal Agencies. This data set is intended to be used as a tool for water-resource management and planning activities, particularly for site-specific and localized studies requiring a level of detail provided by large-scale map information. The dataset is seamless and, for the most part, a nationally consistant geospatial database.</gco:CharacterString>
        </gmd:purpose>
        <gmd:credit>
          <gco:CharacterString>Funding and support for the Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD) were provided by the Natural Resources Conservation Service, the Environmental Protection Agency, and the United States Geological Survey. Representatives from the U.S. Geological Survey and Environmental Protection Agency contributed a substantial amount of time and salary towards quality review and updating of the dataset in order to meet the Federal Standards for Delineation of Hydrologic Unit Boundaries.</gco:CharacterString>

        <gmd:resourceConstraints>
          <gmd:MD_LegalConstraints>
            <gmd:otherConstraints>
              <gco:CharacterString>The distributor shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of this data, based on the description of appropriate/inappropriate uses described in this metadata document. It is strongly recommended that this data is directly acquired from the distributor and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. These data should not be used at scales greater than 1:24,000 for the purpose of identifying hydrographic watershed boundary feature locations in the U.S.A. The U.S. Department of Agriculture makes no claims for the data's suitability for other purposes. U.S. Department of Agriculture should be acknowledged as the data source in products derived from these data. The Watershed Boundary Dataset is public information and may be interpreted by all organizations, agencies, units of government, or others based on needs; however, they are responsible for the appropriate application of the data. Federal, State, or local regulatory bodies are not to reassign to the U.S. Department of Agriculture or the Natural Resources Conservation Service any authority for the decisions they make. The Natural Resources Conservation Service will not perform any evaluations of these maps or purposes related solely to State or local regulatory programs. Photographic or digital enlargement of these maps to scales greater than that at which they were originally delineated can result in misrepresentation of the data. If enlarged, the maps will not include the fine detail that would be appropriate for mapping at the small scale. Digital data files are periodically updated. Files are dated, and users are responsible for obtaining the latest version of the data from the source distributor.</gco:CharacterString>
            </gmd:otherConstraints>
          </gmd:MD_LegalConstraints>
        </gmd:resourceConstraints>

              <gmd:LI_ProcessStep>
                <gmd:description>
                  <gco:CharacterString>Level 5 (10-digit) watersheds were delineated within a nested hierarchical structure using the existing Level 4 (8-digit) watershed delineation as a starting framework. When neccessary, corrections were made to the fourth level line. Level 6 (12-digit) subwatersheds were then nested within the 5th level framework. The typical size of a level 6 watershed is 10,000 to 40,000 acres. The order of precedence for establishing the pour point of a sub-watershed is: (1) at the outlet of a lake or pond; (2) at a confluence; (3) at some topographic feature, such as a natural gap in topography; (4) at a dam; (5) to meet the acreage limitations of the Federal Standard.</gco:CharacterString>
                </gmd:description>
              </gmd:LI_ProcessStep>
            </gmd:processStep>
            <gmd:processStep>
              <gmd:LI_ProcessStep>
                <gmd:description>
                  <gco:CharacterString>Those subbasins that were not transferred to mylar base the following steps were completed: 1) Prior to 2005, each of the paper quad sheets were scanned at a resolution of 600 dpi in black and white. After 2005, the paper quad sheets were scanned at resolution of 300dpi in full color. 2) The resultant image was rotated to a proper cardinal direction orientation and saved 3) The scanned image was imported into ArcMap and georeferenced 4) An empty shapefile was created and defined in ArcCatalog 5) Linework was head's up digitized into this empty shapefile at a scale of approximately 1:11000 ( for those subbasins completed prior to June, 2004); after June, 2004, heads-up digitizing was completed at a scale of approximatley 1:5000. 6) Shapefile was converted to ArcInfo coverage format 7) Line topology and polygon topology were built (to get attribute tables for both) 8) Labels were created 9) Required HUC items were added to the line and polygon attribute tables 10) The coverage projection definition was set to UTM, NAD83 11) HUC code attributes were added to polygons 12) HUC code attributes were added to lines Many agencies contributed to the creation of the dataset using this process; specifically the ND State Water Commission, the U.S. Forest Service, the U.S. Bureau of Reclamation, the ND Game and Fish Department and the ND Department of Health. They all had a hand in creating this dataset, and contributed to it's review and improvement.</gco:CharacterString>
                </gmd:description>
              </gmd:LI_ProcessStep>
            </gmd:processStep>
            <gmd:processStep>
              <gmd:LI_ProcessStep>
                <gmd:description>
                  <gco:CharacterString>For subbasins , 09020313, 10130202, 10130204, 10130205, 10130206,(USGS vectorized) 09020105, 10160001, 10160002, 10160003 (SWC) the original hard copy watershed delineations were transferred to a mylar overlay quad map 1) Each of the mylar sheets were scanned in full color at a resolution of 300dpi 2) The resultant images were rotated to proper cardinal direction orientation and the color depth was reduced to two colors(black and white) and saved 3) Vectorization AML was run to convert the images linework ArcInfo coverage format a) Image was converted to an ArcInfo Grid format b) Grid was vectorized c) Linework was splined d) Coverage was georeferenced and transformed 4) Once all coverages were transformed, all were appended into one large coverage 5) Artifacts from scanned image were deleted including tics, line color script, and basin id script 6) Edgematching clean-up performed 7) Line topology and polygon topology were built (to get attribute tables for both) 8) Labels were created 9) Required HUC items were added to the line and polygon attribute tables 10) The coverage projection definition was set to UTM, zone 14 NAD83 11) HUC code attributes were added to polygons 12) HUC code attributes were added to lines This work was generously completed by the ND State Water Commission and the U.S. Geological Survey Water Resource Office in Bismarck for the subbasins as indicated.</gco:CharacterString>
                </gmd:description>
                <gmd:dateTime>
                  <gco:DateTime>2002-01-01T00:00:00</gco:DateTime>
                </gmd:dateTime>
              </gmd:LI_ProcessStep>
            </gmd:processStep>
            <gmd:source>
              <gmd:LI_Source>
                <gmd:description>
                  <gco:CharacterString>For the Upper Heart, Pembina, Cedar Creek, Lower Cannonball and Upper Cannonball rivers (09020313, 10130202, 10130204, 10130205, 10130206), NRCS personnel delineated hydrologic unit boundaries then inked mylar overlays that were scanned and converted to .rlc format. Scanned lines were then vectorized in ArcInfo. The ND SWC and their contractor, HUD, Inc. completed a similar process for the Devils Lake basin, James River Headwaters, Pipestem, Upper James and Elm-maple rivers. See process step for more description.</gco:CharacterString>
                </gmd:description>
                <gmd:scaleDenominator>
                  <gmd:MD_RepresentativeFraction>
                    <gmd:denominator>
                      <gco:Integer>24000</gco:Integer>
                    </gmd:denominator>
                  </gmd:MD_RepresentativeFraction>
                </gmd:scaleDenominator>
                <gmd:sourceCitation>
                  <gmd:CI_Citation>
                    <gmd:title>
                      <gco:CharacterString>Mylar tracings of hydrologic unit boundaries</gco:CharacterString>
                    </gmd:title>

                        </gmd:dateType>
                      </gmd:CI_Date>
                    </gmd:date>
                    <gmd:citedResponsibleParty>
                      <gmd:CI_ResponsibleParty>
                        <gmd:organisationName>
                          <gco:CharacterString>Natural Resource Conservation Service - ND State Office</gco:CharacterString>
                        </gmd:organisationName>
                        <gmd:role>
                          <gmd:CI_RoleCode codeList="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/resources/codeList.xml#CI_RoleCode" codeListValue="originator" codeSpace="ISOTC211/19115"/>

            </gmd:source>
            <gmd:source>
              <gmd:LI_Source>
                <gmd:description>
                  <gco:CharacterString>Aerial images from the cities of Bismarck, Mandan and Lincoln as well as aerial images from Cass County, ND were used for further refinement of line placement.</gco:CharacterString>
                </gmd:description>
                <gmd:scaleDenominator>
                  <gmd:MD_RepresentativeFraction>
                    <gmd:denominator>
                      <gco:Integer>6000</gco:Integer>

            <gmd:source>

                <gmd:description>
                  <gco:CharacterString>The North Dakota Geological Survey contributed all the 7.5 minute quad maps for this project. They were the base map for all delineations.</gco:CharacterString>
                </gmd:description>
                <gmd:scaleDenominator>

                    </gmd:denominator>

              </gmd:LI_Source>
            </gmd:source>
